title: William J. Burns (diplomat)
added: In January 2021, he was nominated by [[Joe Biden]] to be head of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]].<ref name="MaganCrane">{{cite news |last1=Crane |first1=Magan |title=Biden Picks Long-time Diplomat William Burns to Head CIA |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-11/biden-picks-long-time-diplomat-william-burns-to-head-cia |access-date=11 January 2021 |publisher=Bloomberg |date=January 11, 2021}}</ref>

title: William J. Burns (diplomat)
deleted: In January 2021, he was nominated by [[Joe Biden]] to be head of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]].<ref name="MaganCrane">{{cite news |last1=Crane |first1=Magan |title=Biden Picks Long-time Diplomat William Burns to Head CIA |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-11/biden-picks-long-time-diplomat-william-burns-to-head-cia |access-date=11 January 2021 |publisher=Bloomberg |date=January 11, 2021}}</ref>

title: William J. Burns (diplomat)
deleted: A cable that Burns signed as ambassador to Russia in August 2006, released by [[WikiLeaks]], provided a detailed eyewitness account of the lavish wedding organised in [[Makhachkala]] by Russian [[State Duma]] member and Dagestan Oil Company chief Gadzhi Makhachev for his son. According to Burns′ account of the wedding that lasted for two days and whose attendees included Chechnya′s [[Ramzan Kadyrov]], an [[Federal Security Service|FSB]] colonel was sitting next to them, trying to add "[[cognac]]" to their wine, with an FSB general sitting opposite.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.spiegel.de/international/world/wedding-in-the-caucasus-the-us-ambassador-learns-that-cognac-is-like-wine-a-732370.html|title=Wedding in the Caucasus: The US Ambassador Learns that Cognac Is Like Wine|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|access-date=May 17, 2020|archive-date=January 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210111153904/https://www.spiegel.de/consent-a-?targetUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.spiegel.de%2Finternational%2Fworld%2Fwedding-in-the-caucasus-the-us-ambassador-learns-that-cognac-is-like-wine-a-732370.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2010-12-01|title=US embassy cables: A wedding feast, the Caucasus way|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/76763|access-date=2021-01-13|website=[[The Guardian]]|language=en}}</ref>

title: William J. Burns (diplomat)
added: A cable that Burns signed as ambassador to Russia in August 2006, released by [[WikiLeaks]], provided a detailed eyewitness account of the lavish wedding organised in [[Makhachkala]] by Russian [[State Duma]] member and Dagestan Oil Company chief Gadzhi Makhachev for his son. According to Burns′ account of the wedding that lasted for two days and whose attendees included Chechnya′s [[Ramzan Kadyrov]], an [[Federal Security Service|FSB]] colonel was sitting next to them, trying to add "[[cognac]]" to their wine, with an FSB general sitting opposite.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.spiegel.de/international/world/wedding-in-the-caucasus-the-us-ambassador-learns-that-cognac-is-like-wine-a-732370.html|title=Wedding in the Caucasus: The US Ambassador Learns that Cognac Is Like Wine|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|access-date=May 17, 2020|archive-date=January 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210111153904/https://www.spiegel.de/consent-a-?targetUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.spiegel.de%2Finternational%2Fworld%2Fwedding-in-the-caucasus-the-us-ambassador-learns-that-cognac-is-like-wine-a-732370.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2010-12-01|title=US embassy cables: A wedding feast, the Caucasus way|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/76763|access-date=2021-01-13|website=[[The Guardian]]|language=en}}</ref> In 2015, Burns told [[Gideon Rachman]] of the ''[[Financial Times]]'' that the cable had been "largely written by his colleagues", with Rachman remarking that the cablehad gained a reputation of "a minor classic of comic writing, its tone very much not what one might expect of a diplomatic cable".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/3d4619f6-82f8-11e5-8095-ed1a37d1e096|title=Lunch with the FT: Bill Burns|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=November 6, 2015|archive-date=|archive-url=|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: William J. Burns (diplomat)
added: A cable that Burns signed as ambassador to Russia in August 2006, released by [[WikiLeaks]], provided a detailed eyewitness account of the lavish wedding organised in [[Makhachkala]] by Russian [[State Duma]] member and Dagestan Oil Company chief Gadzhi Makhachev for his son. According to Burns′ account of the wedding that lasted for two days and whose attendees included Chechnya′s [[Ramzan Kadyrov]], an [[Federal Security Service|FSB]] colonel was sitting next to them, trying to add "[[cognac]]" to their wine, with an FSB general sitting opposite.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.spiegel.de/international/world/wedding-in-the-caucasus-the-us-ambassador-learns-that-cognac-is-like-wine-a-732370.html|title=Wedding in the Caucasus: The US Ambassador Learns that Cognac Is Like Wine|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|access-date=May 17, 2020|archive-date=January 11, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210111153904/https://www.spiegel.de/consent-a-?targetUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.spiegel.de%2Finternational%2Fworld%2Fwedding-in-the-caucasus-the-us-ambassador-learns-that-cognac-is-like-wine-a-732370.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=2010-12-01|title=US embassy cables: A wedding feast, the Caucasus way|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/76763|access-date=2021-01-13|website=[[The Guardian]]|language=en}}</ref> In 2015, Burns told [[Gideon Rachman]] of the ''[[Financial Times]]'' that the cable had been "largely written by his colleagues", with Rachman remarking that thetelegram hadgained a reputation of "a minor classic of comic writing, its tone very much not what one might expect of a diplomatic cable".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/3d4619f6-82f8-11e5-8095-ed1a37d1e096|title=Lunch with the FT: Bill Burns|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=November 6, 2015|archive-date=|archive-url=|url-status=live}}</ref>

title: William J. Burns (diplomat)
added: On March 2, 2021, Burns was unanimously approved to be the next director of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) by the Senate Intelligence Committee.<ref>https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/02/senate-approves-burns-cia-472685</ref>

title: William J. Burns (diplomat)
added: In 2008, Burns was nominated by President [[George W. Bush]] and confirmed by the Senate as a [[United States Foreign Service Career Ambassador|Career Ambassador]], the highest rank in the U.S. Foreign Service, equivalent to a four-star general officer in the [[U.S. Armed Forces]]. Promotions to the rank are rare.
